title: About
text:
About me
I am a current Master of Health Science candidate of epidemiology in Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. During my undergraduate and graduate study, I have been trained in skills of Statistics and Epidemiology, and specifically concentrated on Clinical and Cardiovascular Epidemiology. I developed strong analytical skills of managing and analyzing data using R, Stata and SAS, and I am proficient in longitudinal and survival analysis for clinical trials and large longitudinal data. In addition, I am also pursuing a certificate in Public Health Economics.

title: Part 3
text:
Use wget to download the students.csv file locally from here.

{bash echo=TRUE}     wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/stephaniehicks/jhustatprogramming2024/refs/heads/main/projects/01-project/students.csv

Display the contents of the students.csv file using the cat command.

{bash echo=TRUE}     cat students.csv

Display only the first 5 lines of the file using head to show the first few lines.

{bash echo=TRUE}     head -n 5 students.csv

Display only the last 3 lines of the file using tail to show the last few lines.

{bash echo=TRUE}     tail -n 3 students.csv

Count the number of lines in the file using the wc command to count the lines.

{bash echo=TRUE}     wc students.csv

Find all students who are taking “Math” as a subject using grep to filter lines with the subject “Math”.

{bash echo=TRUE}     grep -w "Math" students.csv

Find all female students using grep or awk to filter based on gender.

{bash echo=TRUE}     grep -w "F" students.csv

Sort the file by the students’ ages in ascending order. Use sort to order by the “Age” column.

{bash echo=TRUE}     (head -n 1 && tail -n +2 | sort -t',' -k3,3n) < students.csv

Find the unique subjects listed in the file. Use cut, sort, and uniq to extract unique subjects.

{bash echo=TRUE}     tail -n +2 students.csv | cut -d',' -f6 | sort | uniq

Calculate the average grade of the students. Use awk to sum the grades and divide by the number of students.

{bash echo=TRUE}     awk -F"," 'NR > 1 {sum += $3; count++} END {if (count > 0) print  "Average Grade: ", sum/count}' students.csv

Replace all occurrences of “Math” with “Mathematics” in the file. Use sed to perform the replacement.

{bash echo=TRUE}    tail -n +2 students.csv | sed 's/Math/Mathematics/g' students.csv

title: Example analysis
text:
Research question: Whether drinking certain types of milk with certain fat content for regular consumption is associated with obesity or overweight in adults in US.
Intended audience: US adults aged 18-80.
Data source: This study is a cross-sectional study using data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES), 2017-March 2020 Pre-Pandemic cycle(Health Statistics 2018). NHANES is a program of studies designed to assess the health and nutritional status of adults and children in the United States. Due to the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, data collected from 2019 to March 2020 were combined with data from the NHANES 2017-2018 cycle to form a nationally representative sample of NHANES 2017-March 2020 pre-pandemic data.
Link: https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/continuousnhanes/default.aspx?Cycle=2017-2020
Data dictionary:







Variables
Description




Subject ID
The exclusive ID of each subject


Weight status
Defined based on BMI. Obesity/overweight is defined as BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2, and normal/underweight is defined as BMI < 25 kg/m2(Piché, Tchernof, and Després 2020).


Type of milk
The type of milk usually consumed in the past 30 days


Age
Age at baseline


Sex
Sex at birth


Race/ethnicity
Race/ethnicity at birth


Education level
Education level at baseline


Family poverty income ratio
Family poverty income ratio at baseline


Physical activity level
Active PA is defined as meeting or exceeding 600 MET-min/week, as per the physical activity guidelines established in the USA. Conversely, inactive PA is defined as falling below 600 MET-min/week(Chudasama et al. 2019).


Energy intake
Energy intake on Day 1



Statistical Analysis:
Since NHANES provided survey data, certain weights were applied to adjust for the distribution of the population. Missing data was handled using complete case analysis because the dataset was large enough that bias were minimized.
Multivariable logistic regression models will be used to estimate the association between whole milk consumption and the odds of obesity/overweight compared to normal/underweight, respectively. The results will be shown using odds ratios (ORs) and confidence intervals (95%CIs). The first model will only includes exposure variable, and the second model will be adjusted for potential confounding covariables. All statistical analysis was conducted with R 4.2.2.

Result:
Data description:
The study included 7555 participants without missing exposure status before weighting and 190,923,999 after weighting. The median age (IQR) was 57 (43, 70), 47 (33, 63), 47 (32, 62), 44 (30, 59) and 44 (30, 61) in fat-free, 1%, 2%, whole fat and other milk group. Those who drinks fat-free milk tended to be older, female and non-Hispanic White, with higher education level and income, while those who drinks whole fat milk tended to be younger, male and non-White (mainly non-Hispanic Black), with lower education level and income (Table 1).
Table 1. Characteristics of participants by types of milk consumption






library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(haven)


demo_data <- read_xpt("https://wwwn.cdc.gov/Nchs/Nhanes/2017-2018/DEMO_J.XPT")

length(unique(demo_data$SEQN))

[1] 9254



demo_data <- demo_data %>% mutate(sex=ifelse(demo_data$RIAGENDR==1, 0, 1))

demo_data <- demo_data %>% mutate(Sex=factor(demo_data$sex, level=c(0,1), label=c("Male","Female")))

table(demo_data$Sex)


  Male Female 
  4557   4697 



body_data <- read_xpt("https://wwwn.cdc.gov/Nchs/Nhanes/2017-2018/BMX_J.XPT")

nhanes_2017_20<- left_join(demo_data, body_data, by = "SEQN")


nhanes_2017_20 <-nhanes_2017_20 %>%
       mutate(
         bmicat = case_when(
           BMXBMI<25 ~ 0,
           BMXBMI>=25 ~ 1,
           .default = NA))

nhanes_2017_20 <- nhanes_2017_20 %>% mutate(bmicategory=factor(nhanes_2017_20$bmicat, level=c(0,1), label=c("Normal/underweight", "Obesity/overweight")))

table(nhanes_2017_20$Sex, nhanes_2017_20$bmicategory)

        
         Normal/underweight Obesity/overweight
  Male                 1757               2140
  Female               1883               2225

nhanes_obesity <- nhanes_2017_20 %>% filter(bmicategory=="Obesity/overweight") %>% select(SEQN,Sex,BMXBMI)

nhanes_sex <- nhanes_2017_20 %>% group_by(Sex)







Tip



To simplify the category of BMI, normal weight and underweight were grouped together, and obesity and overweight were group together.



ggplot(nhanes_2017_20, aes(BMXBMI, Sex)) + geom_boxplot() + labs(x = "BMI", y = "Sex", title = "Boxplot of BMI by Sex")

Warning: Removed 1249 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_boxplot()`).










ggplot(nhanes_2017_20, aes(x = RIDAGEYR, y = BMXBMI,color = Sex)) + geom_point(size = 0.1) + facet_grid(vars(Sex)) + labs(x = "Age", y = "BMI", title = "BMI distribution by Age")

Warning: Removed 1249 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).










ggplot(nhanes_2017_20, aes(x=BMXBMI)) + geom_histogram( binwidth=3, fill="#69b3a2", color="#e9ecef", alpha=0.9) + labs(x = "BMI", title = "Histogram of BMI")

Warning: Removed 1249 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_bin()`).















Note



BMI is the short form of Body Mass Index, which is calculated by weight over the square of height.



knitr::kable(
  nhanes_2017_20[1:6, 1:6]
)

Summary
The results of regression analysis showed that before adjusting for other factors, only drinking whole fat milk was statistically significantly associated with lower risk of obesity or overweight (OR: 0.55, p = 0.007). However, after adjusting for race/ethnicity, sex, age, education level, family poverty income ratio, physical activity and energy intake, the association was eliminated (OR: 0.64, p = 0.077). None of the types of milk appeared to have an association with obesity or overweight (Table 2).



Used function:

dplyr: filter(), select(), mutate(), left_join(), group_by()
ggplot2: geom_boxplot(), geom_point(), geom_histogram(), facet_grid()






References

Chudasama, YV, KK Khunti, F Zaccardi, et al. 2019. “Physical Activity, Multimorbidity, and Life Expectancy: A UK Biobank Longitudinal Study.” BMC Medicine 17 (1): 108. https://doi.org/10.1186/s12916-019-1339-0.


Health Statistics, National Center for. 2018. “National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.” https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/.


Piché, M. E., A. Tchernof, and J. P. Després. 2020. “Obesity Phenotypes, Diabetes, and Cardiovascular Diseases.” Circulation Research 126 (11): 1477–1500. https://doi.org/10.1161/CIRCRESAHA.120.316101.

title: Welcome to my world!
text:
Hi! My name is Yishan Lin. I am not an AI, so I can’t show everything about myself to you here, but I am glad to introduce my biography and a little bit about my current thoughts. I hope you will find it interesting and would like to talk with me in person one day!

Fun things about me
I like animes and one of my favorite is Psycho-Pass, a Japanese anime.





Source: (johndavis_1994 2020)





References

johndavis_1994. 2020. “Psycho-Pass-Live-Action-Fan-Casting-Poster-62094-Medium.” https://www.mycast.io/stories/psycho-pass-live-action.
